p: Moreover, in view of the rising interest towards polymer nanocomposites, due to their improved mechanical thermal and barrier properties [ 79, 80], some researchers have recently studied the of recycling biobased nanocomposites [ 19, 63, 81]. With particular reference to PLA, it is known that this polymer undergoes thermodegradation during melt processing [ 76, 82] and, therefore, its recyclability is strictly related to the actual extent of thermodegradative phenomena during melt processing [ 76, 83, 84]. For instance, Tesfaye et al. [ 81] investigated the effect of silk nanocrystals (SNC) on thermal and rheological properties of PLA subjected to repeated extrusion operations; they found that the presence of SNC slows down the thermal degradation of PLA. Peinado et al. [ 63] studied the effects of extrusion on the rheological and mechanical properties of PLA filled with nanoclays; they found that, although both PLA and nanocomposites show viscosity decreases after each processing step, there was no major reduction of the mechanical performance.
